subsection.leadIn: It is not a contravention of subsection (1), (2) or (3) for a person other than a solicitor to employ a trainee solicitor so along as—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the trainee solicitor is assigned to a solicitor who acts as his principal;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the solicitor who acts as principal is qualified under and complies with subsections (1), (2) and (3); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the solicitor is employed by the same person as the trainee solicitor. (Added 60 of 1994 s. 21)

subsection.leadIn: Any—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: solicitor; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: qualified person,

subsection.continued: serving in the—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: Department of Justice; or (Amended L.N. 362 of 1997)

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: the Legal Advisory and Conveyancing Office of the Lands Department; or (Replaced 8 of 1993 s. 20. Amended L.N. 291 of 1993)

paragraph.name: iia
paragraph.content: the Land Registry; or (Added 8 of 1993 s. 20)

paragraph.name: iib
paragraph.content: the Companies Registry; or (Added 8 of 1993 s. 20)

paragraph.name: iii
paragraph.content: Legal Aid Department; or (Amended 39 of 1992 s. 11)

paragraph.name: iv
paragraph.content: Official Receiver’s Office; or (Added 39 of 1992 s. 11. Amended 60 of 1992 s. 6)

paragraph.name: v
paragraph.content: Intellectual Property Department, (Added 60 of 1992 s. 6)

subsection.continued: of the Government shall, for the purpose of this section, be deemed to be practising as a solicitor on his own account; and this subsection shall apply in relation to periods before as well as periods after the commencement of the Legal Practitioners (Amendment) Ordinance 1982 (50 of 1982). (Added 50 of 1982 s. 4)

section.name: s21
section.heading: Power to prohibit employing trainee solicitors

subsection.content: Where the Society refuses to issue a practising certificate to a solicitor under section 6, the Council may by notice in writing to that solicitor prohibit him from employing a trainee solicitor or acting as the principal of a trainee solicitor. (Amended 52 of 1980 s. 2; 70 of 1991 s. 13; 60 of 1994 s. 22)

section.name: s22
section.heading: Power to terminate trainee solicitor contracts in certain cases

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: during the term of a trainee solicitor contract a trainee solicitor has been continuously absent from the place of business of his principal for a period of 3 months or such longer period as may be prescribed by the Council except for such reason as may be prescribed by the Council; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Council is for any other reason of the opinion that a trainee solicitor contract ought to be terminated,

section.continued: the Council may, on application of the solicitor, the trainee solicitor or any other person, terminate the trainee solicitor contract on such terms as it shall think fit and may determine what, if any, of the period of employment of the trainee solicitor shall be effective for the purposes of this Ordinance.

section.name: s23
section.heading: Termination of trainee solicitor contracts in cases of bankruptcy, etc.
section.content: If a solicitor who employs a trainee solicitor or acts as his principal becomes bankrupt before the expiration of the trainee solicitor contract or is imprisoned for debt and remains in prison for more than 21 days, the Court, on the application of any person, may order the trainee solicitor contract to be terminated or to be assigned to another solicitor on such terms and in such manner as the Court thinks fit.

section.name: s24
section.heading: Society’s general right of audience
section.leadIn: The Society shall have a general right of audience by any member of the Society appointed for that purpose by the Society or by any counsel, before—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Solicitors Disciplinary Tribunal; and (Amended 61 of 1992 s. 6)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Court on the hearing of any matter under this Ordinance that does not solely affect barristers, (Replaced 60 of 1994 s. 24)

section.continued: and in any such case, whether the Society has or is seeking audience or not, the Society shall be served with a copy of every necessary document filed with the Registrar.

section.name: s25
section.heading: Expenses of Solicitors Disciplinary Tribunal and of Society

subsection.leadIn: The expenses incurred by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Solicitors Disciplinary Tribunal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Society, in connection with proceedings before a Solicitors Disciplinary Tribunal, the Court of Appeal and the Court of Final Appeal,

subsection.continued: may be paid to the Society out of general revenue upon a certificate issued by the Secretary for Justice.

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary for Justice shall only issue a certificate under subsection (1) if he is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the expenses were necessarily incurred by the Solicitors Disciplinary Tribunal or the Society, as the case may be, in exercise of the powers or duties conferred or imposed by this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the amount of such expenses is reasonable; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the expenses could not reasonably be recovered from the person whose conduct is the subject of the proceedings before the Solicitors Disciplinary Tribunal, the Court of Appeal or the Court of Final Appeal, as the case may be. (Amended 92 of 1975 s. 59; 46 of 1989 s. 6)

subsection.def: In this section, expenses (開支) includes witnesses’ expenses and fees, counsel’s fees, solicitor’s fees, auditor’s fees and other charges and disbursements.

section.name: s26
section.heading: Statutory provisions to prevail over Society’s articles
section.content: In the case of any inconsistency between the provisions of this Ordinance and the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Society the provisions of this Ordinance shall prevail.

part.name: P2A
part.heading: Circumstances in which Law Society may intervene

section.name: s26A
section.heading: Circumstances in which powers conferred by Schedule 2 exercisable

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), the powers conferred by Schedule 2 shall be exercisable where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the Council has reason to suspect dishonesty on the part of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a solicitor or foreign lawyer; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: an employee or a trainee solicitor of a solicitor or foreign lawyer; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the personal representatives of a deceased solicitor or foreign lawyer, in connection with that solicitor’s or foreign lawyer’s practice or in connection with any trust of which that solicitor or foreign lawyer immediately before the date of his death or formerly was a trustee,

paragraph.continued: and the Council considers the exercise of those powers is in the interests of the public or the clients of the solicitor or foreign lawyer;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Council considers that there has been undue delay on the part of the personal representatives of a deceased solicitor or foreign lawyer who immediately before his death was practising as a solicitor in his own name or as a sole solicitor or foreign lawyer under a firm name in connection with that solicitor’s or foreign lawyer’s practice or in connection with any controlled trust;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the Council is satisfied that a solicitor or foreign lawyer has failed to comply with rules made by virtue of section 73(1)(b) or 73A;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a solicitor or foreign lawyer has become bankrupt or has entered into a voluntary arrangement with his creditors within the meaning of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6); (Amended 27 of 1998 s. 7)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: a solicitor or foreign lawyer has been committed to prison in any civil or criminal proceedings;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: the Council is satisfied that a solicitor or foreign lawyer who practises as a solicitor in his own name or as a sole solicitor or foreign lawyer under a firm name is incapacitated by illness or accident to such an extent as to be unable to attend to his practice;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: the powers conferred by section 10D of the Mental Health Ordinance (Cap. 136) (emergency powers) or section 11 of that Ordinance (appointment of committee) have been exercised in respect of a solicitor or foreign lawyer; (Replaced 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: the name of a solicitor has been removed from or struck off the roll or a solicitor has been suspended from practice or the registration of a foreign lawyer is cancelled or suspended;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: the Council is satisfied that a solicitor or foreign lawyer who practises as a solicitor in his own name or as a sole solicitor or foreign lawyer under a firm name has abandoned his practice;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: the Council is satisfied that a solicitor or foreign lawyer who practises as a solicitor in his own name or as a sole solicitor or foreign lawyer under a firm name is incapacitated by age to such an extent as to be unable to attend to his practice;

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.content: any power conferred by this Part and Schedule 2 has been exercised by virtue of paragraph (a) in relation to a solicitor or foreign lawyer who practises as a solicitor in his own name or as a sole solicitor or foreign lawyer under a firm name and he has acted as a solicitor or foreign lawyer who practises as a solicitor in his own name or as a sole solicitor or foreign lawyer under a firm name within the period of 18 months beginning with the date on which it was so exercised;

paragraph.name: l
paragraph.content: the Council is satisfied that a person has acted as a solicitor at a time when he did not have a practising certificate which was in force;

paragraph.name: m
paragraph.leadIn: the Council is satisfied that a solicitor has failed to comply with any condition, subject to which his practising certificate was granted or otherwise has effect, to the effect that he may act as a solicitor only—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in employment which is approved by the Council in connection with the imposition of that condition;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: as a member of a partnership which is so approved; or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: in any specified combination of those ways;

paragraph.name: n
paragraph.content: the Council is satisfied that a solicitor or foreign lawyer has failed to make satisfactory arrangements within 21 days from the date of the closure of his practice.

subsection.content: The powers conferred by Schedule 2 shall only be exercisable under subsection (1)(c), (j), (k), (l) and (m) if the Council has given the solicitor notice in writing that the Council is satisfied that he has failed to comply with rules specified in the notice and also (at the same or any later time) notice that the powers conferred by Schedule 2 are accordingly exercisable in his case.

subsection.leadIn: In this Part and Schedule 2—
subsection.def: controlled trust (受控制信託), in relation to a solicitor or foreign lawyer, means a trust of which he is a sole trustee or co-trustee only with one or more of his partners, employees or trainee solicitors;

trust (信託) includes an implied or constructive trust and a trust where the trustee has a beneficial interest in the trust property, and also includes the duties incidental to the office of a personal representative, and trustee (受託人) shall be construed accordingly.

section.name: s26B
section.heading: Death of sole solicitor or foreign lawyer
section.content: On the death of a solicitor or foreign lawyer who practises as a solicitor in his own name or as a sole solicitor or foreign lawyer under a firm name sections 2, 3 and 4 of Schedule 2 shall apply to the client accounts of his practice.

section.name: s26C
section.heading: Undue delay by solicitors or foreign lawyers in connection with clients’ instructions
section.leadIn: The powers conferred by Schedule 2 shall also be exercisable, subject to sections 1(4) and 8(3) of that Schedule, where—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a complaint is made to the Council that there has been undue delay on the part of a solicitor or foreign lawyer in connection with any matter in which the solicitor or his firm or the foreign lawyer or his firm was instructed on behalf of a client or with any controlled trust; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Council by notice in writing invites the solicitor or foreign lawyer to give an explanation within a period of not less than 8 days specified in the notice; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the solicitor or foreign lawyer fails within that period to give an explanation which the Council regards as satisfactory; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the Council gives notice of the failure to the solicitor or foreign lawyer and (at the same or any later time) notice that the powers conferred by Schedule 2 are accordingly exercisable.

section.name: s26D
section.heading: Powers conferred by Schedule 2 exercisable after death of solicitor

subsection.content: Where the powers conferred by Schedule 2 are exercisable in relation to a solicitor or foreign lawyer, they shall continue to be exercisable after his death or after his name has been removed from or struck off the roll (in the case of a solicitor) or his registration is cancelled or suspended (in the case of a foreign lawyer).

The references to the solicitor or his firm or the foreign lawyer or his firm in sections 1(1), 2(2) and (3), 3, 7(1) and (5) and 8(1) of Schedule 2 include, in any case where the solicitor or foreign lawyer has died, references to his personal representatives.
subsection.referenceNote: [cf. 1974 c. 47 Sch. 1 Pt. I U.K. as amended by 1990 c. 41 s. 91 U.K.]

section.name: s27AA
section.heading: Interpretation (Part III)

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—
subsection.def: Admission Rules (《認許規則》) means the Barristers (Admission) Rules (Cap. 159 sub. leg. AA);
CE certificate (行政長官證明書) means a certificate issued by the Chief Executive under Article 47 of the HK National Security Law;

HK National Security Law (《香港國安法》) means the Law of the People’s Republic of China on Safeguarding National Security in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (a translation of “《中華人民共和國香港特別行政區維護國家安全法》”), as applied in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under the Promulgation of National Law 2020 (L.N. 136 of 2020)*;
notice of permission to proceed (准許進行申請通知書) means a notice of permission to proceed issued by the Chief Executive, as referred to in section 27C(5).

subsection.leadIn: To avoid doubt, for sections 27B, 27C, 27D and 27E—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a reference to a case is a reference to a case of any nature, whether criminal, civil or otherwise; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: a reference to a case concerning national security includes, but is not limited to—

subparagraph.content: a case in connection with an offence under the HK National Security Law or any other offence endangering national security; and
a case in connection with any measures taken for, or in connection with, safeguarding national security, whether under the HK National Security Law or any other law.

tr.td: See Promulgation of National Law 2020—The Law of the People’s Republic of China on Safeguarding National Security in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region (Instrument A302).

section.name: s27
section.heading: Power of Court to admit barristers

subsection.leadIn: Subject to subsection (2), the Court may, in such manner as may be prescribed by the Chief Justice, admit as a barrister of the High Court in Hong Kong, a person whom it considers a fit and proper person to be a barrister, provided such person has—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: complied with the requirements;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: passed the examinations; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: paid the fees,

subsection.continued: prescribed by the Bar Council.

subsection.leadIn: The Court shall not admit a person under subsection (1) unless it is satisfied that that person—

paragraph.name: a
b
paragraph.leadIn: satisfies one of the following requirements—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: has resided in Hong Kong for at least 3 consecutive months immediately before the date of his application for admission;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: has been ordinarily resident in Hong Kong for at least 7 years;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: has been physically present in Hong Kong for at least 180 days of each of at least 7 years within the 10 years immediately preceding the date of his application for admission.

subsection.content: If at the time of his admission under subsection (1) the person is a solicitor, the Registrar shall remove the person’s name from the roll of solicitors.

subsection.leadIn: Notwithstanding that a person does not satisfy all the requirements specified in subsections (1) and (2)(b), where the Court considers that he is a fit and proper person to be a barrister and is satisfied that he has—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the qualification acquired outside Hong Kong to engage in work that would, if undertaken in Hong Kong, be similar to that undertaken by a barrister in the course of ordinary practice as a barrister in the High Court or Court of Final Appeal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: substantial experience in advocacy in a court,

subsection.continued: the Court may admit such person as a barrister under this section for the purpose of any particular case or cases and may impose such restrictions and conditions on him as it may see fit.

subsection.name: 4A
subsection.content: Subsection (4) is subject to sections 27B, 27C, 27D, 27E and 27F. (Added 7 of 2023 s. 4)
The Court may, when admitting a person as a barrister, sit in chambers.

editorialNote.content: For the saving provision in relation to the amendment made by section 7 of the Legal Practitioners (Amendment) Ordinance 2000 (42 of 2000), please see section 17 of that Amendment Ordinance.

section.name: s27B
section.heading: Generally, no admission as barrister for cases concerning national security under section 27(4)

subsection.content: A person must not be admitted as a barrister for a case concerning national security under section 27(4) unless there is exceptional circumstance as specified in subsection (2).

The exceptional circumstance is that the Chief Executive has sufficient grounds for believing that the person’s practising or acting as a barrister for the case does not involve national security or would not be contrary to the interests of national security.
Sections 27C, 27D, 27E and 27F contain provisions in relation to establishing whether the exceptional circumstance exists.

section.name: s27C
section.heading: No application for admission as barrister for cases concerning national security under section 27(4) without notice of permission to proceed

subsection.content: A person (applicant) intending to seek to be admitted as a barrister for a case (or cases) concerning national security under section 27(4) must, before making an application under section 2 of the Admission Rules, notify the Secretary for Justice in writing of the applicant’s intention.

subsection.leadIn: The notification must be accompanied by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the documents referred to in section 2(4)(a), (b) and (c) of the Admission Rules; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a written statement personally signed by the applicant and (if the applicant is represented by a solicitor) the solicitor, showing grounds that the applicant’s practising or acting as a barrister for the case (or any of the cases) does not involve national security or would not be contrary to the interests of national security.

subsection.content: The applicant and the solicitor must also provide with the statement any documents or other evidence in support of the grounds.

The Secretary for Justice must, as soon as practicable after receiving the notification under subsection (1) and the documents, written statement and evidence mentioned in subsections (2) and (3), refer the matter to the Chief Executive.

The Chief Executive will issue a notice of permission to proceed in respect of the application only if the Chief Executive considers that there is a real prospect that the exceptional circumstance specified in section 27B(2) exists.
The Secretary for Justice must, as soon as practicable after receiving a notice of permission to proceed from the Chief Executive, send the notice to the applicant.

If the Chief Executive decides not to issue a notice of permission to proceed, the Secretary for Justice must, as soon as practicable after receiving the decision from the Chief Executive, notify the applicant in writing of the decision.

If the notice of motion filed by the applicant for the application is not accompanied by a notice of permission to proceed issued in respect of the case (or cases), the Court must not take any further action in respect of the notice of motion, including fixing a hearing date of the motion.

subsection.leadIn: Subsections (10), (11) and (12) apply if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a person seeks to be admitted as a barrister for a case under section 27(4), and the application made by the person under section 2 of the Admission Rules is not accompanied by a notice of permission to proceed issued in respect of the case; but

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: it appears to the Court or the Secretary for Justice that the case is a case concerning national security.

subsection.content: The Court must, on its own motion or on request of the Secretary for Justice, request and obtain a certificate from the Chief Executive under Article 47 of the HK National Security Law on whether the case is a case concerning national security.

Unless the Court receives a certificate under subsection (10) certifying that the case is not a case concerning national security, the Court must not take any further action in respect of the application, including fixing a hearing date of the application, until the person obtains a notice of permission to proceed in accordance with this section.

If the Court is notified by the Secretary for Justice that the Chief Executive has decided not to issue a notice of permission to proceed in respect of the application, the Court must dismiss the application immediately.

section.name: s27D
section.heading: Court not to admit barrister for cases concerning national security under section 27(4) without CE certificate

subsection.leadIn: Before making any order as to the admission of a person for a case concerning national security, the Court must request and obtain a certificate from the Chief Executive under Article 47 of the HK National Security Law on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether the person’s practising or acting as a barrister for the case involves national security; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether the person’s practising or acting as a barrister for the case would be contrary to the interests of national security.

subsection.leadIn: The Court must not admit the person as a barrister for the case under section 27(4) unless the Court receives a CE certificate certifying both or either of the following decisions of the Chief Executive—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person’s practising or acting as a barrister for the case does not involve national security;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the person’s practising or acting as a barrister for the case would not be contrary to the interests of national security.

section.name: s27E
section.heading: Questions arising after admission under section 27(4) that require referral to Chief Executive

subsection.leadIn: After a person is admitted as a barrister for a case under section 27(4), if it appears to the relevant court or the Secretary for Justice that there are new circumstances giving rise to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: whether a decision certified in respect of the case by a CE certificate under section 27D(2) (previous certificate) remains appropriate; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: whether the case is a case concerning national security,

subsection.continued: the relevant court must, on its own motion or on request of the Secretary for Justice, request and obtain in respect of the case a CE certificate certifying the questions referred to in section 27D(1) (new certificate).

subsection.content: The specified proceedings must be stayed until the relevant court receives a new certificate, unless otherwise ordered by the relevant court on the ground that it is in the interests of justice that the specified proceedings should continue without the person’s practising or acting as a barrister for the case.

If the Chief Executive, on request of the relevant court under subsection (1), issues a new certificate in respect of the case, the new certificate replaces the previous certificate issued in respect of the case (if any), and the previous certificate ceases to have effect.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: relevant court (有關法院), in relation to specified proceedings, means the court in which the proceedings are pending;
specified proceedings (指明程序), in relation to a case, means the proceedings of the case for which a person is admitted under section 27(4).

section.name: s27F
section.heading: No questioning of, and no legal proceedings be instituted in respect of, decision of Chief Executive
section.content: A decision made by the Chief Executive under section 27C, 27D or 27E is not liable to be questioned in any court of law, and no legal proceedings of any form may be instituted in respect of the decision.

section.name: s28
section.heading: Formalities for admission as a barrister
section.content: Except as may be prescribed by the Chief Justice, no person shall be admitted as a barrister unless he has deposited with the Registrar documentary evidence together with an affidavit showing the manner in which he satisfies the requirements specified in section 27(1) and (2).

section.name: s29
section.heading: Roll of barristers

subsection.content: The Registrar shall keep a roll of all barristers admitted by the Court under sections 27 and 27A and shall have custody of the roll of barristers and of all documents relating thereto and shall allow any person to inspect the roll of barristers during office hours without payment. (Amended 61 of 1992 s. 15)

The Registrar, upon production of a certificate of admission signed by a judge and upon payment to the Registrar of such fee as may be prescribed by the Chief Justice, shall enter upon the roll of barristers the name of the person enrolled. (Amended 60 of 1994 s. 31)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.leadIn: A barrister who was admitted pursuant to section 27(1) or section 27A may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: apply by motion to have his name removed from the roll of barristers; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where he has had his name removed under paragraph (a), on giving at least 7 days’ notice to the Bar Council, apply by motion to have his name restored to the roll of barristers. (Added 42 of 2000 s. 10)

subsection.name: 2B
subsection.content: A barrister who was admitted pursuant to section 27(4) for a particular case or cases shall, on completion of such case or cases including any appeal relating thereto, be deemed to have had his name removed from the roll of barristers. (Added 42 of 2000 s. 10)

subsection.name: 2C
subsection.content: Where a barrister has had his name removed from the roll of barristers under subsection (2A) or (2B), he shall forthwith surrender to the Bar Council any current practising certificate. (Added 42 of 2000 s. 10)

section.name: s30
section.heading: Practising certificates—barristers

content.leadIn: The Bar Council, upon application in writing by a barrister and upon payment of such fee as may be prescribed by the Bar Council and upon being satisfied in such manner as may be prescribed by the Bar Council that the person to whom the application relates is qualified to practise as a barrister or is qualified to practise to a limited extent under section 31(2), shall issue to the applicant a practising certificate as a barrister in such form as may be prescribed by the Bar Council for the period of one calendar year from 1 January next following the date of the application: (Amended 25 of 1968 s. 10; 58 of 1976 s.9; 42 of 2000 s. 11)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Bar Council, in its absolute discretion and upon such condition as it may consider necessary, may permit the application for a practising certificate to be made under this subsection at any time and upon such application may issue to the applicant a practising certificate for any period not exceeding one calendar year and ending on 31 December in any year; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where the name of a barrister is removed from or struck off the roll of barristers, the practising certificate of that barrister shall automatically determine without any entitlement to any refund of the prescribed fee or of any part thereof.

subsection.content: The publication in the Gazette by the Bar Council of a list of the names and addresses of those barristers who have obtained practising certificates for the period therein stated shall be prima facie evidence that each person named therein is a person qualified under section 31 to practise as a barrister and to whom a practising certificate for the period specified in such list has been issued under this section and the absence from any such list of the name of any person shall be prima facie evidence that such person is not so qualified.

subsection.leadIn: A practising certificate may only be issued to an applicant who has paid to the Hong Kong Bar Association—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: except where the Bar Council has exempted the applicant therefrom, the membership subscription; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: except where the applicant has been admitted as a barrister under section 27(4) and the Bar Council has exempted him therefrom, the premium prescribed for insurance of the applicant under the current master policy for professional indemnity insurance effected by the Hong Kong Bar Association,

subsection.continued: in respect of the period for which the practising certificate is to be issued. (Replaced 42 of 2000 s. 11)

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: On application by a barrister admitted under section 27(4), the Bar Council may waive part of the membership subscription. (Added 42 of 2000 s. 11)

section.name: s31
section.heading: Qualifications for practising as a barrister

subsection.leadIn: A barrister shall not be qualified to practise as such—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to subsection (2), unless he has completed the prescribed qualifying period of active practice;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: unless he holds a valid practising certificate;

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.content: for a barrister admitted under section 27(4) for a case (or cases) concerning national security, unless the Chief Executive issues, in respect of the barrister for the case (or cases), a CE certificate certifying both or either of the decisions under section 27D(2), and the certificate remains in effect; (Added 7 of 2023 s. 6)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: having qualified for admission as a barrister by virtue of section 27(1)(a)(i) or (ii) (as that section existed before its repeal by the Legal Practitioners (Amendment) Ordinance 2000 (42 of 2000)), unless he continues to be a barrister in England or Northern Ireland or an advocate in Scotland and is not there suspended from practice as such; (Amended 42 of 2000 s. 12)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: if he is suspended from practice under section 37; (Amended 61 of 1992 s. 16)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: if he is on the roll of solicitors; (Replaced 70 of 1991 s. 7. Amended 61 of 1992 s. 16; 42 of 2000 s. 12)

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: if he is an employed barrister within the meaning of section 31C(1). (Added 42 of 2000 s. 12)

subsection.content: After the expiry of the first 6 months of the prescribed qualifying period of active practice, a barrister shall be qualified to practise as a barrister to such limited extent as the Bar Council may determine.

section.name: s31A
section.heading: Appointment of Senior Counsel

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Justice may, after consultation with the chairman of the Bar Council and the president of the Society, appoint any of the following persons who satisfies the eligibility requirements set out in subsection (2) as a Senior Counsel— (Amended 24 of 2021 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a barrister;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person (not being a barrister) who holds office as a legal officer.

subsection.leadIn: A person is eligible for appointment as a Senior Counsel if the person— (Amended 24 of 2021 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has, in the opinion of the Chief Justice, sufficient ability and standing as a barrister or legal officer, and sufficient knowledge of the law, to be accorded that status; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has the requisite experience; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is practising at the bar in Hong Kong or is practising as an advocate while holding office as a legal officer.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (2)(b), a person has the requisite experience for appointment as a Senior Counsel if the person has, for not less than 10 years in aggregate, done one or both of the following— (Amended 24 of 2021 s. 3)

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: practised at the bar in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: practised as an advocate while holding office as a legal officer.

subsection.name: 3A
subsection.content: If the Chief Justice appoints a person mentioned in subsection (1)(b) as a Senior Counsel, the person is entitled to use the title, and to enjoy the status, of Senior Counsel only while holding office as a legal officer. (Added 24 of 2021 s. 3)

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Justice may, after consultation with the chairman of the Bar Council and the president of the Society, appoint a barrister as honorary Senior Counsel if he—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is a member of the academic staff of a faculty or school of law of a university in Hong Kong; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: holds office as Director of Legal Aid or as a Deputy Director or Assistant Director of Legal Aid; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: holds office as Official Receiver or an office specified in Part I of Schedule 2 to the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6); or

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: holds office as Director of Intellectual Property or an office specified in Part I of Schedule 1 to the Director of Intellectual Property (Establishment) Ordinance (Cap. 412),

subsection.continued: and who has, in the Chief Justice’s opinion, provided distinguished service to the law of Hong Kong.

subsection.content: The appointment of a person as a Senior Counsel in an honorary capacity does not confer on the person a right to act as an advocate in proceedings before the courts of Hong Kong and will not accord precedence before the courts.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: legal officer (律政人員) has the meaning given by section 2 of the Legal Officers Ordinance (Cap. 87), and includes a person deemed to be a legal officer for the purposes of that Ordinance. (Added 24 of 2021 s. 3)

editorialNote.content: For the savings and transitional provisions in relation to the status of Queen’s Counsel, please see section 2 of Schedule 2 to the Legal Services Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Ordinance 1997 (94 of 1997).

section.name: s31B
section.heading: Status of visiting Queen’s Counsel
section.content: A Queen’s Counsel of another jurisdiction who is appearing in legal proceedings before a court in Hong Kong is entitled to use the title, and to be accorded the status, of Senior Counsel for the purposes of those proceedings.

section.name: s31C
section.heading: Employed barristers

subsection.def: In this section employed barrister (受僱大律師) means a barrister who, under a contract of employment, provides legal services exclusively to his employer.

subsection.leadIn: An employed barrister may apply to the Bar Council for an employed barrister’s certificate if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: at any time, he has been issued a practising certificate under section 30; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: he has completed the prescribed qualifying period of active practice; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: he has been an employed barrister in Hong Kong for at least 12 months immediately preceding the date of his application.

subsection.content: An employed barrister may be issued an employed barrister’s certificate and the provisions of sections 29(2C) and 30 (except section 30(3)(b)) respecting practising certificates apply to employed barrister’s certificates issued under this section and, for the purposes of this section, references in those sections to a barrister or a practising certificate shall be deemed to be references to an employed barrister and an employed barrister’s certificate respectively. (Amended 26 of 2012 s. 3)

The publication in the Gazette by the Bar Council of a list of the names and addresses of those barristers who have obtained employed barrister’s certificates for the period therein stated shall be prima facie evidence that each person named therein is the holder of such a certificate for the period specified in such list, and the absence from any such list of the name of any person shall be prima facie evidence that the person does not hold such a certificate.

An employed barrister who holds a current employed barrister’s certificate may, on behalf of his employer but for the purpose of obtaining a legal opinion only, instruct a barrister who holds a current practising certificate, without retaining a solicitor.

section.name: s33
section.heading: Bar Council—general right of audience
section.leadIn: The Bar Council shall have a general right of audience, by any member of the Bar Council appointed for that purpose by the Bar Council or by any other counsel—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: before a Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: before the Court on the hearing of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any application to the Court for admission and enrolment as a barrister; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any proceedings in the Court relating to, affecting or touching any matter affecting the qualification or examination of a person seeking to be a barrister or affecting the privileges, restrictions or offences in connection with the professional practice, conduct and discipline of a barrister,

section.continued: and in any such case, whether the Bar Council has or is seeking audience or not, the Bar Council shall be served with a copy of every necessary document filed with the Registrar.

section.name: s34
section.heading: Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal Panel

subsection.leadIn: The Chief Justice is required to appoint a Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal Panel consisting of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: no fewer than 6 and no more than 15 practising Senior Counsel of Hong Kong; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: no fewer than 6 and no more than 20 other practising barristers of at least 7 years’ standing; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: no fewer than 5 and no more than 25 lay persons who are not, in the opinion of the Chief Justice, in any way connected with the practice of the law. (Replaced 94 of 1997 s. 8)

subsection.content: A member of the Bar Council is not eligible to be appointed to or remain on the Panel.
A person appointed to the Panel shall be appointed for a term specified by the Chief Justice not to exceed 5 years but may be reappointed for a further term or terms.

The Chief Justice shall appoint one of the barristers on the Panel as the Tribunal Convenor for a 3 year term and he may appoint one or more other barristers on the Panel as Deputy Tribunal Convenors for 3 year terms.

A Deputy Tribunal Convenor designated by the Tribunal Convenor may act in place of the Tribunal Convenor whenever the Tribunal Convenor is prevented from exercising the Tribunal Convenor’s functions because of illness, absence from Hong Kong or any other cause. (Added 94 of 1997 s. 8)

editorialNote.content: For the savings and transitional provisions in relation to the amendment made by section 8(1) of the Legal Services Legislation (Miscellaneous Amendments) Ordinance 1997 (94 of 1997), please see section 3 of Schedule 2 to the Ordinance.

section.name: s35
section.heading: Complaint about barrister’s conduct

subsection.content: Where the Bar Council considers that the conduct of a barrister should be inquired into as a result of a complaint being made to it or otherwise, the Bar Council shall submit the matter to the Tribunal Convenor of the Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal Panel.

Where a complaint is made to the Bar Council and the Bar Council does not submit a matter to the Tribunal Convenor under subsection (1) within 6 months after receiving the complaint the Chief Judge may, on application by any person or on his own initiative, submit the matter to the Tribunal Convenor if he considers that the Bar Council ought to have done so. (Amended 23 of 2002 s. 107)

A matter submitted to the Tribunal Convenor must include or be accompanied by particulars of the conduct that is to be inquired into and by particulars of any associated allegations of misconduct. (Added 94 of 1997 s. 9)

section.name: s35A
section.heading: Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal

subsection.leadIn: On receiving a submission under section 35, the Tribunal Convenor of the Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal Panel is required to appoint from the Panel—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Senior Counsel; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a barrister who is not a Senior Counsel; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a lay person.

subsection.content: The persons so appointed constitute a Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal to inquire into the conduct of the barrister concerned.
When constituting a Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal, the Tribunal Convenor is also required to appoint one of its members as chairman of the Tribunal.

subsection.leadIn: A Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal may be constituted by the chairman and by one other member designated by the chairman for the purposes only of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: giving directions or making orders for the conduct of an inquiry under section 36; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: announcing the findings of the Tribunal with respect to the inquiry.

subsection.content: A member of a Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal who becomes a member of the Bar Council ceases to be a member of the Tribunal.

section.name: s35B
section.heading: Sittings of Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal

subsection.content: A Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal is required to sit at such places and at such times as the chairman of the Tribunal directs.
A Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal is required to hold its proceedings in camera, except when the barrister whose conduct is being inquired into requests that the proceedings be open to the public.

section.name: s36
section.heading: Powers of Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: A Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal may inquire into the conduct of any person in respect of which it was constituted. (Added 61 of 1992 s. 20)

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of conducting an inquiry, a Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal shall have all such powers as are vested in the Court or in any judge in the course of any action or suit in respect of the following matters—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: enforcing the attendance of witnesses and examining them upon oath or otherwise;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: compelling the production of documents;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: punishing persons guilty of contempt;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: ordering an inspection of any property;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: conducting every examination of witnesses; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: adjourning any meeting from time to time and from one place to another,

subsection.continued: and a summons under the hand of the chairman of a Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal may be substituted for and shall be equivalent to any form of process capable of being issued in any action or suit for compelling the attendance of witnesses or the production of documents and any warrant of committal to prison issued for the purpose of enforcing any such powers must be signed by the chairman but must not authorize the imprisonment of any offender for a period exceeding 1 month. (Amended 94 of 1997 s. 12)

subsection.content: The Commissioner of Police and all police officers, officers of the court, gaolers and bailiffs of the court are required to give their utmost assistance to every Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal and to every chairman thereof, in the enforcement of documents, warrants and orders issued in accordance with subsection (1) or otherwise.

Every member of a Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal shall have the like protection and privileges, in relation to any action or suit brought against him for any act done or omitted to be done in the execution of his duties as such member, as is given by any law to a magistrate acting in the execution of his office.
All proceedings of a Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal are privileged. (Replaced 61 of 1992 s. 20)

subsection.leadIn: A Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal constituted to inquire into the conduct of a person may inquire into other conduct of the person, but only if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person has been given reasonable notice and adequate particulars of that other conduct; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Tribunal is satisfied that that other conduct is related to the first-mentioned conduct. (Added 94 of 1997 s. 12)

subsection.leadIn: The power conferred by subsection (5) is exercisable only on the application of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Bar Council in the case of a matter submitted to the Tribunal Convenor under section 35(1); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Chief Judge in the case of a matter submitted to the Tribunal Convenor under section 35(2). (Added 94 of 1997 s. 12. Amended 23 of 2002 s. 108)

subsection.content: Notice is not reasonable for the purposes of subsection (5) if it is less than 7 days. (Added 94 of 1997 s. 12)

A Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal may make such order as to the payment by a party to an inquiry of the costs incurred in conducting the inquiry as it thinks just. Such an order may direct that the costs are to be taxed by a Master of the High Court on a full indemnity basis. (Added 94 of 1997 s. 12. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

section.name: s37
section.heading: Disciplinary powers of Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal
section.leadIn: On completion of its inquiry, the Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal may do one or more of the following—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: censure the barrister;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: suspend the barrister from practising for a period it specifies;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: order that the barrister’s name be struck off the roll of barristers;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: order the barrister to pay to the complainant an amount not exceeding the amount or amounts paid or payable to the barrister in relation to the complainant’s matters in dispute;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: order the barrister to pay a penalty not exceeding $500,000, which shall be paid into the general revenue;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: order the barrister to pay the costs of and incidental to the proceedings of the Tribunal and the costs of any prior inquiry or investigation in relation to the matters before the Tribunal, to be taxed by a Master of the High Court on a full indemnity basis, or an amount that the Tribunal considers to be a reasonable contribution towards those costs; (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: make any other order it thinks fit.

section.name: s37A
section.heading: Findings of a Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal

subsection.content: An order made by a Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal shall include a statement of its findings in relation to the facts of the case and shall be signed by the chairman or by a member authorized by the Tribunal.

A signed copy of an order of a Tribunal shall be filed with the Registrar who shall enter a note of the order on the roll of barristers against the name of the barrister and, where the order so directs, the Registrar shall strike off the name and shall publish an order for suspension or striking off in the Gazette within 14 days after receiving a copy of the order.

The Tribunal that heard the matter or a Tribunal constituted for the purpose by the Tribunal Convenor may, on the application of a party against whom an order for payment is made, order that payment may be paid by instalments or be deferred for a period the Tribunal considers appropriate.

An application for an order for payment by instalments, or for the deferring of payment, may be made at the hearing or, within 14 days after the date of the order for payment, by notice in writing to the Tribunal Convenor and to all parties who were represented at the Tribunal hearing.
On receipt of a notice under subsection (4), the Tribunal Convenor shall, within 14 days, notify the applicant and the other parties of the date on which the application will be heard by a Tribunal.
There is no right of appeal from the decision of the Tribunal on an application under subsection (4).

Payment of an amount ordered to be paid by the Tribunal may be enforced as if it were an order issued out of the Court on the production of a copy of the order signed by the chairman or other authorized member of the Tribunal and the rules of the Court, so far as applicable, apply to the order.
No order under subsection (7) shall be enforced until after the 14 days referred to in subsection (4) has elapsed or until after the Tribunal has made its decision under subsection (3).

section.name: s37B
section.heading: Appeal to Court of Appeal

subsection.content: A person who is the subject of an order under section 37 or 38 may appeal to the Court of Appeal and Order 59 of the Rules of the High Court (Cap. 4 sub. leg. A) applies to the appeal except that the time for serving the notice of appeal is 21 days from the date of the decision and not 28 days as provided in Order 59. (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2; 10 of 2005 s. 58; 10 of 2008 s. 32)
In an appeal under this section the Bar Council shall be the respondent.
The hearing of an appeal under this section shall be in open court unless, and to the extent to which, the Court of Appeal otherwise directs.

section.name: s38
section.heading: Variation of order of the Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal

subsection.content: Any barrister who has been suspended from practising or whose name has been struck off the roll may apply to the Tribunal Convenor of the Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal Panel to have a Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal constituted for the purpose of hearing his application to vary or discharge the order suspending him or striking his name off the roll.

subsection.leadIn: No application shall be made under subsection (1)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of an order of suspension, until the expiration of 2 years from the date of such order or of half the period of suspension, whichever is the less; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of an order striking the name of the barrister off the roll, until the expiration of 2 years from the date of such order,

subsection.continued: and in either case where such an application has been made and determined, no further application shall be made until the expiration of 2 years from the date of such determination:
subsection.proviso: Provided that the barrister may at any time apply on the grounds that new material facts have come to light since the making of the order which it is sought to vary or discharge, and where the Tribunal Convenor is of the opinion that such facts should be placed before a Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal, he shall grant such application.

subsection.leadIn: At the hearing of the application the Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: reduce the period of suspension; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: discharge the order of suspension or the order striking the name of the barrister off the roll, as the case may be; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: confirm the original order; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: make such order as to costs as it shall see fit.

section.name: s39
section.heading: Expenses of Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal and of Bar Council

subsection.leadIn: The expenses incurred by—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Bar Council, in connection with proceedings before a Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal, the Court of Appeal and the Court of Final Appeal,

subsection.continued: may be paid to the Bar Council out of general revenue upon a certificate issued by the Secretary for Justice.

subsection.leadIn: The Secretary for Justice shall only issue a certificate under subsection (1) if he is satisfied that—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the expenses were necessarily incurred by the Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal or the Bar Council, as the case may be, in exercise of the powers or duties conferred or imposed by this Ordinance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the amount of such expenses is reasonable; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the expenses could not reasonably be recovered from the barrister whose conduct is the subject of the proceedings before the Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal, the Court of Appeal or the Court of Final Appeal, as the case may be.

subsection.def: In this section, expenses (開支) includes witnesses’ expenses and fees, counsel’s fees, solicitor’s fees, auditor’s fees and other charges and disbursements.

section.name: s39A
section.heading: Foreign lawyers

subsection.content: The Society may register as a foreign lawyer a person who, not being a solicitor who holds a practising certificate or a barrister who holds a practising certificate, is qualified to practise foreign law.
Solicitor-client privilege exists between a foreign lawyer and his client to the same extent as the privilege exists between a solicitor and his client.
Where a foreign lawyer becomes bankrupt the registration of the foreign lawyer is automatically cancelled. (Amended 27 of 1998 s. 7)

section.name: s39B
section.heading: Foreign firms

subsection.leadIn: The Society may register as a foreign firm a firm—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in which all of the partners who intend to practise in Hong Kong are foreign lawyers or the sole practitioner of which is a foreign lawyer; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: that intends to have within 2 months after registration, a place of business in Hong Kong for the purpose of practising or advising on foreign law.

subsection.content: Where a firm was registered as a foreign firm on the basis of an intention referred to in subsection (1)(b) but fails to establish a place of business in Hong Kong within 2 months after its registration, the Society may cancel the firm’s registration.

section.name: s39C
section.heading: Associations

subsection.content: The Society may register as an Association a Hong Kong firm and one or more foreign firms if the Hong Kong firm and the foreign firm or firms have, or intend to have within 2 months after the registration, an agreement under which fees, profits, premises, management or employees are shared between the Hong Kong firm and the foreign firm or firms.

Where the Hong Kong firm and the foreign firm or firms fail to enter into an agreement referred to in subsection (1) within 2 months after registration of the Association, the Society may cancel the Association’s registration.

section.name: s39D
section.heading: Hong Kong firms may employ foreign lawyers
section.content: Subject to rules made under section 73(1)(dc), a Hong Kong firm may employ a foreign lawyer.

section.name: s39E
section.heading: Higher Rights Assessment Board

subsection.content: A board to be known as the Higher Rights Assessment Board is established.

subsection.leadIn: The Assessment Board—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: has the functions conferred on it by or under this or any other Ordinance; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has the powers conferred on it by or under this or any other Ordinance, and all other powers necessary to perform its functions.

subsection.leadIn: The Assessment Board consists of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a chairperson appointed by the Chief Justice, who must be an eligible person;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: 9 other members appointed by the Chief Justice, of whom—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: 2 must be eligible persons;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: 3 must be solicitors who engage in litigation work in the course of ordinary practice;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: 3 must be Senior Counsel; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: one must be a Law Officer or a Principal Government Counsel of the Department of Justice; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: one other member selected by the chairperson from among the members of the panel appointed by the Chief Justice under subsection (5).

subsection.leadIn: Before making an appointment under subsection (3)(b)(ii), (iii) or (iv), the Chief Justice must consult—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of an appointment under subsection (3)(b)(ii), the President of the Society;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of an appointment under subsection (3)(b)(iii), the Chairman of the Hong Kong Bar Association; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of an appointment under subsection (3)(b)(iv), the Secretary for Justice.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (3)(c), the Chief Justice may appoint a panel of persons whom the Chief Justice considers suitable for selection as members of the Assessment Board and who are not, in the opinion of the Chief Justice, connected in any way with the practice of law.

subsection.leadIn: A person who is appointed as the chairperson of the Assessment Board under subsection (3)(a) may be paid from the general revenue any remuneration that the Chief Executive considers appropriate, but only if the person is an eligible person under that subsection by reason of being—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a non-permanent Hong Kong judge of the Court of Final Appeal (other than a non-permanent Hong Kong judge of the Court of Final Appeal who is also a Justice of Appeal of the Court of Appeal); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a person who was formerly a judge of the High Court (other than a recorder or a deputy judge of the Court of First Instance) but who is not a permanent judge or a non-permanent Hong Kong judge of the Court of Final Appeal.

def.name: EligiblePerson
def.leadIn: In this section, eligible person (合資格人士)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: means—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: a permanent judge or a non-permanent Hong Kong judge of the Court of Final Appeal;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: a judge of the High Court (other than a recorder or a deputy judge of the Court of First Instance); or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: a person who was formerly a judge of the High Court (other than a recorder or a deputy judge of the Court of First Instance) but who is not a permanent judge or a non-permanent Hong Kong judge of the Court of Final Appeal; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the purposes of subsection (3)(b)(i), includes a judge of the District Court (other than a deputy judge of the District Court).

section.name: s39F
section.heading: Further provisions relating to members of Assessment Board or of panel appointed under section 39E(5)

subsection.content: A member of the Assessment Board or of the panel appointed under section 39E(5) holds office for a term not exceeding 3 years, but may be reappointed or reselected.
A member of the Assessment Board or of the panel appointed under section 39E(5) may at any time resign from office by giving notice in writing to the Chief Justice.

Subject to subsection (4), the Chief Justice may at any time remove from office any member of the Assessment Board or of the panel appointed under section 39E(5) by giving notice in writing to the member.

subsection.leadIn: Before removing from office any member of the Assessment Board appointed under section 39E(3)(b)(ii), (iii) or (iv), the Chief Justice must consult—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a member appointed under section 39E(3)(b)(ii), the President of the Society;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the case of a member appointed under section 39E(3)(b)(iii), the Chairman of the Hong Kong Bar Association; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in the case of a member appointed under section 39E(3)(b)(iv), the Secretary for Justice.

section.name: s39G
section.heading: Further provisions relating to proceedings of Assessment Board

subsection.leadIn: The quorum for a meeting of the Assessment Board is 7 members, of whom—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: one must be the chairperson of the Board or a member appointed under section 39E(3)(b)(i);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: one must be a member appointed under section 39E(3)(b)(ii); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: one must be a member appointed under section 39E(3)(b)(iii).

subsection.leadIn: At a meeting of the Assessment Board—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: subject to paragraph (b), the chairperson of the Board must preside; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: if the chairperson is not present at the meeting, a member of the Board appointed under section 39E(3)(b)(i) and nominated by the chairperson must preside.

subsection.content: Each member of the Assessment Board present at a meeting of the Board has one vote.

subsection.leadIn: A decision on any matter at a meeting of the Assessment Board must be supported—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the case of a decision to make any rules under section 73CA, by the votes of at least 6 members of the Board present and voting on that matter; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in any other case, by a majority of votes of the members of the Board present and voting on that matter.

subsection.content: For the purposes of subsection (4)(b), if on any matter the votes are equally divided, the person presiding at the meeting of the Assessment Board, in addition to having one vote under subsection (3), has a casting vote.
Subject to the other provisions of this Ordinance, the Assessment Board may regulate its own procedure.

section.name: s39H
section.heading: Application to Assessment Board for higher rights of audience

subsection.content: A solicitor who satisfies the eligibility requirements under section 39I may apply to the Assessment Board for higher rights of audience.

subsection.leadIn: The applicant must specify in the application one of the following classes of proceedings as the class of proceedings in respect of which the applicant is applying for higher rights of audience—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: civil proceedings;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: criminal proceedings;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: both civil and criminal proceedings.

subsection.def: For the purposes of this Ordinance, higher rights of audience (較高級法院出庭發言權) means rights of audience before the Competition Tribunal, the High Court and the Court of Final Appeal, whether in civil proceedings, criminal proceedings, or both, but does not include any of those rights that solicitors generally may from time to time have apart from this Ordinance. (Amended 15 of 2014 s. 14)

section.name: s39I
section.heading: Eligibility requirements

subsection.leadIn: An applicant under section 39H satisfies the eligibility requirements if the applicant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: holds a current practising certificate as a solicitor;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has the requisite experience;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: has complied with the requirements prescribed by rules made under section 73CA(1)(a)(i); and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: has not, in the same calendar year in which the application is made, made any other application under section 39H (whether in respect of the same or a different class of proceedings).

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1)(b), the applicant has the requisite experience if, during the period of 7 years immediately before the date of the application, the applicant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: has, for not less than 2 years in the aggregate, done one or more of the following—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: practised as a solicitor in Hong Kong;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: practised as a barrister in Hong Kong;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: practised as a legal officer within the meaning of section 2 of the Legal Officers Ordinance (Cap. 87) or held a similar office; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: has, for not less than 3 further years in the aggregate, done one or more of the following—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: practised as a solicitor in Hong Kong;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: practised as a barrister in Hong Kong;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: practised as a legal officer within the meaning of section 2 of the Legal Officers Ordinance (Cap. 87) or held a similar office;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: practised the law of any other common law jurisdiction while being qualified to do so under the law of that jurisdiction, whether or not also under this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (1)(c)—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the applicant may elect to make the application on the basis of exemption from the requirements referred to in that subsection by stating in the application that the applicant has so elected; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: on the applicant making the election under paragraph (a), that subsection does not apply to the applicant.

def.name: SimilarOffice
def.leadIn: In this section, similar office (相類職位) means—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an office held by a person by an appointment under section 3(1) of the Legal Aid Ordinance (Cap. 91); or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: an office the holder of which is deemed to be a legal officer for the purposes of the Legal Officers Ordinance (Cap. 87) under section 3(3) of the Director of Intellectual Property (Establishment) Ordinance (Cap. 412) or section 75(3) of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6).

section.name: s39J
section.heading: Further requirements concerning application

subsection.leadIn: An application under section 39H must be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in the form specified by the Assessment Board;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: supported by the information prescribed by rules made under section 73CA(1)(a)(ii);

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: accompanied by the fee prescribed by rules made under section 73CA(1)(a)(iii); and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: made within any of the periods specified under subsection (3).

subsection.content: The fee referred to in subsection (1)(c) is payable to the Government.

The Assessment Board must, in relation to each calendar year, specify, by notice published in any manner that it considers appropriate, one or more periods during which applications may be made under section 39H.

section.name: s39K
section.heading: Determination of application by Assessment Board

subsection.content: As soon as practicable after an application is made to it under section 39H, the Assessment Board must consider the application, and decide whether to grant or refuse the application.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), if the class of proceedings in respect of which the applicant is applying for higher rights of audience is that specified in section 39H(2)(c), the Assessment Board may grant the application—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: without modifications to the class of proceedings to which the application relates; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: only in respect of a class of proceedings specified in section 39H(2)(a) or (b).

subsection.leadIn: As soon as practicable after a decision is made under subsection (1), the Assessment Board must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: notify the applicant of—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the decision; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: if it grants the application under subsection (2)(b) or refuses the application, the reasons for the decision; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: notify the Council of the decision.

section.name: s39L
section.heading: Conditions for granting application

subsection.leadIn: Without affecting any other requirements applicable to an application made under section 39H, the Assessment Board may grant the application only if it is satisfied that the applicant—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the applicant has elected to make the application on the basis of exemption from the requirements referred to in section 39I(1)(c), has complied with the alternative requirements prescribed by rules made under section 73CA(1)(a)(iv);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: has acquired sufficient experience in litigation work in the course of ordinary practice within the period of 3 years immediately before the date of the application, so as to be a suitable person to have the higher rights of audience in respect of which the Board is to grant the application; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: is in all other respects a suitable person to have the higher rights of audience in respect of which the Board is to grant the application.

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), the Assessment Board—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in considering whether the applicant satisfies the requirement under subsection (1)(b), must accord due weight to the applicant’s experience in advocacy work, whether written or oral; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in considering whether the applicant satisfies the requirement under subsection (1)(c), may have regard to—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the applicant’s competence in advocacy work, whether written or oral;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the applicant’s professional conduct and integrity; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: any other matters that the Board considers relevant.

section.name: s39M
section.heading: Further provisions applicable to determination of application

subsection.leadIn: In considering an application under section 39H, the Assessment Board may—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the purpose of ascertaining whether the applicant satisfies the eligibility requirements under section 39I or the further requirements described in section 39L(1)(a), (b) and (c), make any enquiries with the Council that the Board considers appropriate; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: require the applicant to provide it with any further information relating to the application that it considers appropriate, whether at any interview before it or in any other manner that it considers appropriate.

subsection.leadIn: In considering the application, the Assessment Board may have regard to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: any matter made available to it under this Part; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: any other matters that it considers relevant.

subsection.content: If the Assessment Board proposes to grant the application under section 39K(2)(b) or to refuse the application, it must give the applicant an opportunity to make representations, whether in writing or in any other manner that it considers appropriate.

section.name: s39N
section.heading: Applicant having higher rights of audience on grant of application
section.leadIn: On the granting by the Assessment Board of an application made under section 39H—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the applicant has the higher rights of audience in respect of which the Board has granted the application; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: those rights are exercisable by the applicant as a solicitor.

section.name: s39O
section.heading: Loss of higher rights of audience

subsection.leadIn: A person who has higher rights of audience under this Part ceases to have those rights on—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the person being adjudged bankrupt under the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: the person’s name ceasing to be on the roll of solicitors—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: as a result of an order made under section 10(2)(a);

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: under section 19(1); or

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: under any other provision of this Ordinance; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: the person being suspended from practice as a solicitor—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: as a result of an order made under section 10(2)(b); or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: under any other provision of this Ordinance.

subsection.leadIn: Despite subsection (1), the person reacquires the higher rights of audience—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: if the person has been adjudged bankrupt as described in subsection (1)(a), on the person being discharged from bankruptcy under the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: if the person’s name has ceased to be on the roll of solicitors as described in subsection (1)(b), on—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the case of subsection (1)(b)(i), the person’s name being restored to the roll of solicitors on an appeal against the order referred to in that subsection; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of subsection (1)(b)(i), (ii) or (iii), the person’s name being restored to the roll of solicitors under section 5(3); or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: if the person has been suspended from practice as a solicitor as described in subsection (1)(c), on—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: in the case of subsection (1)(c)(i), the person’s suspension being set aside on an appeal against the order referred to in that subsection; or

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: in the case of subsection (1)(c)(i) or (ii), the period of the person’s suspension having expired.

section.name: s39P
section.heading: Higher rights of audience certificate

subsection.content: As soon as practicable after being notified under section 39K(3) of the granting by the Assessment Board of an application in respect of any higher rights of audience, the Council must issue to the person by whom the application has been made a certificate in respect of those rights.

If under section 39O(1) the person ceases to have higher rights of audience (whether or not only for a specified period), any certificate issued to the person under this section in respect of those rights also ceases to have effect.

If, after any certificate issued to the person has ceased to have effect under subsection (2), the person reacquires under section 39O(2) the higher rights of audience covered by the certificate, the certificate is again to have effect on the reacquisition by the person of those rights.

If the Council is required to issue a certificate to any person under subsection (1), and the person also has higher rights of audience under this Part in respect of any class of proceedings other than those to which the certificate relates, the Council may, where it considers appropriate, issue to the person a certificate in respect of all higher rights of audience that the person has under this Part.
If a certificate is issued to a person under subsection (4), any earlier certificate issued in respect of any of the higher rights of audience covered by the certificate ceases to have effect.
A certificate issued under this section must be in a form prescribed by rules made under section 73(1)(de).

section.name: s39Q
section.heading: List of persons with higher rights of audience

subsection.content: The Council must keep a list of all persons who have acquired higher rights of audience under this Part, whether or not they have subsequently ceased to have those rights.

subsection.leadIn: The list must, in relation to those persons, contain—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: their respective names and, in relation to any of the persons who have not ceased to have the higher rights of audience, the respective addresses at which they carry on their businesses of practising as a solicitor;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the respective dates from which they have acquired the higher rights of audience and, where applicable, the respective dates from which or during which they have ceased to have those rights; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the respective classes of proceedings to which the higher rights of audience relate.

subsection.content: As soon as practicable after becoming aware of any matter that would reasonably require the list to be updated, the Council must update the list accordingly.
As soon as practicable after updating the list, the Council must provide a copy of the updated list to the Registrar.

For the purpose of enabling any member of the public to ascertain whether a person has acquired higher rights of audience under this Part and to ascertain the particulars of those rights, the Council must make the list available for public inspection at the office of the Council during office hours without payment.

section.name: s39R
section.heading: Code of conduct for solicitor advocates

subsection.content: The Council may, in consultation with the Chief Justice and the Bar Council, issue a code of conduct for the purpose of setting out standards of professional conduct to be observed by solicitor advocates.
