subparagraph.content: exempting, in any particular case, a person seeking admission under section 4 or 27 or appointment under section 40A from compliance with all or any of the conditions prescribed for such admission or appointment by this Ordinance, subject to such conditions as may appear necessary; (Amended 60 of 1994 s. 44; 27 of 1998 s. 5)

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: providing for the duties of the Registrar in connection with such admissions and appointments; (Amended 27 of 1998 s. 5)

subparagraph.name: vi
vii
subparagraph.content: prescribing any fees payable in connection with such admissions and appointments; (Amended 27 of 1998 s. 5)

subparagraph.name: x
subparagraph.content: regulating the granting of exemption from the provisions of any of such rules and of the compliance with any terms imposed upon the grantees of such exemption and prescribing the form of any statutory declaration evidencing such compliance;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to the conduct of barristers, to provide for—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the making of a complaint to the Tribunal Convenor of the Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal Panel;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the conduct of proceedings before a Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the procedure for making and hearing an application under section 38; and (Replaced 61 of 1992 s. 25)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: generally to prescribe or provide for—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: any other certificate, form or other document required under this Ordinance;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: any other fee which is required to be prescribed under this Ordinance;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the better carrying into effect of the provisions of this Ordinance; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: anything which under this Ordinance is to be or may be prescribed by the Chief Justice.

section.name: s72A
section.heading: Rules for barristers in Hong Kong
section.leadIn: The Chief Justice may make rules in relation to the admission of persons who seek to qualify or have qualified as barristers in Hong Kong—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: regulating the enrolment of students seeking to become barristers in Hong Kong;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: regulating the manner in which pupillage may be served, including applications for pupillage, disqualifications in respect of pupillage, approval and termination of pupillage and the period and requirements of pupillage; (Replaced 58 of 1976 s. 12)

paragraph.name: ba
paragraph.content: regulating the examinations to be passed by students seeking to become barristers in Hong Kong; (Added 58 of 1976 s. 12)

paragraph.name: bb
paragraph.content: prescribing the qualifying period of active practice for the purposes of section 31; (Added 58 of 1976 s. 12. Amended 42 of 2000 s. 15)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: generally for the better control of such students.

section.name: s72AA
section.heading: Power of Bar Council to make rules
section.leadIn: Subject to the prior approval of the Chief Justice, the Bar Council may make rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in respect of the professional practice, conduct and discipline of barristers and pupils;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the purpose of harmonizing the relationship of barristers inter se and, with the prior approval of the Council, governing the relationship of solicitors and barristers;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: regulating the issuing of practising certificates to barristers and employed barrister’s certificates to employed barristers including, without limiting the foregoing, the fees payable for, the conditions of issue of, the manner of applying for, the period and form of and the publication of the issue and suspension of, such certificates;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: providing for any continuing legal education or training that must be undertaken by barristers and pupils and the consequences of failing to do so;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: providing for the conduct of an inquiry and investigation by a Barristers Disciplinary Tribunal;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: requiring a barrister or pupil whose conduct has been established to the satisfaction of the Bar Council to amount to a breach of proper professional standards to pay the Bar Council’s costs of investigating the conduct which resulted in the order;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: regulating the serving of pupillage and the manner in which any person shall qualify for admission under section 27, including, without limiting the foregoing, the period of pupillage and the examinations to be passed;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: respecting the admission of persons on the basis of qualifications acquired outside Hong Kong including, without limiting the foregoing, the qualifications for admission, the examinations to be passed and the fees to be paid;

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: respecting the exemption by it of any person from compliance with the provisions of any rules made under this section and the conditions upon which such exemption may be granted in any particular case; and

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: prescribing anything which, under this Ordinance, is to be or may be prescribed by the Bar Council.

section.name: s72AB
section.heading: Conflict between rules made by Chief Justice and Bar Council

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the Chief Justice; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Bar Council,

section.continued: to make rules in respect of the same matter, rules made by either or both of them in respect of such a matter shall be valid unless there is a conflict between such rules, in which case the rules made by the Chief Justice shall be given precedence to the extent of such conflict.

section.name: s73
section.heading: Power of the Council to make rules

subsection.leadIn: The Council may make rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: providing for—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the professional practice, conduct and discipline of solicitors, solicitor advocates, foreign lawyers, employees of solicitors and foreign lawyers and trainee solicitors; (Replaced 60 of 1994 s. 45. Amended 2 of 2010 s. 8)

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the restriction of payment of commission to unqualified persons; and

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: for the purpose of harmonizing the relationship of solicitors inter se and, with the prior approval of the Bar Council, governing the relationship of solicitors and barristers; (Amended 70 of 1991 s. 8)

paragraph.name: aa
paragraph.content: regulating the issue to solicitors of practising certificates and the fees payable for, the conditions of issue of, the manner of applying for, the period and form of, the publication of the issue and the suspension of such practising certificates and generally in relation thereto; (Added 58 of 1976 s. 13)

paragraph.name: ab
paragraph.content: providing for any continuing legal education or training that must be undertaken by solicitors; (Added 70 of 1991 s. 10)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to the keeping by solicitors of accounts, providing for—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the opening and keeping by solicitors of accounts at banks of clients’ money;

subparagraph.name: ii
iii
iv
v
subparagraph.content: the qualifications to be held by an accountant by whom an accountant’s report may be given; (Amended 25 of 1968 s. 14)

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: the nature and extent of the examination to be made by the accountant of the books and accounts of a solicitor or of his firm and of any other relevant documents with a view to the signing of a report to be delivered by the solicitor under section 8; (Amended 25 of 1968 s. 14)

subparagraph.name: vii
subparagraph.content: the form of an accountant’s report and the information to be contained therein in accordance with section 8(1); (Replaced 25 of 1968 s. 14)

subparagraph.name: viii
subparagraph.content: the evidence, if any, which shall satisfy the Council that the delivery of an accountant’s report is unnecessary and the cases in which such evidence is or is not required; (Amended 25 of 1968 s. 14; L.N. 162 of 1993)

subparagraph.name: ix
x
subparagraph.content: regulating any matters of procedure or matters incidental, ancillary or supplemental to the provisions of section 8;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: providing for the conduct of an inquiry and investigation by a Solicitors Disciplinary Tribunal; (Amended 61 of 1992 s. 26)

paragraph.name: caa
paragraph.content: providing for the practice and procedure to be followed in connection with the submission of a matter by the Council to the Tribunal Convenor under section 9A(1A); (Added 23 of 2002 s. 111)

paragraph.name: cab
paragraph.content: providing for the practice and procedure to be followed in connection with the disposal of a matter by the Tribunal Convenor under section 9AB; (Added 23 of 2002 s. 111)

paragraph.name: ca
paragraph.content: respecting procedures for investigations by an inspector under section 8AA; (Added 60 of 1994 s. 45)

paragraph.name: cb
paragraph.content: requiring a solicitor, foreign lawyer, trainee solicitor or employee to whom a letter of disapproval is sent by the Council, to pay the Council’s costs of investigating the conduct which resulted in the letter of disapproval; (Added 60 of 1994 s. 45)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.leadIn: regulating the employment of trainee solicitors and examinations, and in particular, without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing, providing for— (Amended 32 of 1972 s. 4; 1 of 1981 s. 5; 70 of 1991 s. 13)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the manner in which any person shall qualify for admission under section 4(1)(a) including, in particular, the period of employment, if any, of a trainee solicitor in any particular case, the examination or examinations to be passed, the courses to be completed and notices and forms to be used in connection therewith; (Amended 1 of 1981 s. 5; 70 of 1991 ss. 10 & 13; 60 of 1994 s. 45; E.R. 2 of 2019)

paragraph.name: da
paragraph.content: respecting the admission of persons under section 4(1)(b), including the qualifications for admission, examinations and the fees to be paid for applications and examinations; (Added 60 of 1994 s. 45)

paragraph.name: db
paragraph.content: respecting the registration of foreign lawyers, foreign firms and Associations, including applications for registration, qualification for registration, fees for application and registration, period and form of registration, conditions of registration, suspension of registration and cancellation of registration; (Added 60 of 1994 s. 45)

paragraph.name: dc
paragraph.content: respecting the practice of Hong Kong firms, foreign firms and Associations; (Added 60 of 1994 s. 45)

paragraph.name: dd
paragraph.content: prohibiting the practice of Hong Kong law by foreign lawyers and for that purpose the Council may define, limit or expand the meaning of the practice of Hong Kong law; (Added 60 of 1994 s. 45)

paragraph.name: de
paragraph.content: regulating the issue to solicitor advocates of higher rights of audience certificates and the form of, and other matters relating to, the certificates; (Added 2 of 2010 s. 8)

paragraph.name: df
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to the practice of limited liability partnerships—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: prescribing particulars for the purposes of section 7AI(1)(e); and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: regulating any matters of procedure or matters incidental, ancillary or supplemental to the provisions of Part IIAAA; (Added 22 of 2012 s. 7)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: enabling the Council to exempt any person from compliance with the provisions of any such rules and to impose and enforce conditions upon which such exemption may be granted in any particular case; and

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: prescribing any thing which, under this Ordinance, is to be or may be prescribed by the Council. (Amended 52 of 1980 s. 2)

subsection.content: Every rule made by the Council under this section shall be subject to the prior approval of the Chief Justice. (Amended 52 of 1980 s. 2)

subsection.name: 2A
subsection.def: For the avoidance of doubt, it is declared that in subsection (1)(a)(i), professional practice (專業執業), in relation to a solicitor, means acting as a solicitor or the business of acting as a solicitor, whether as a partner, sole practitioner, assistant solicitor or consultant in a Hong Kong firm or as an employee of a non-solicitor employer. (Added 10 of 2005 s. 185)

subsection.content: No rule made under subsection (1)(b), (c) or (d) shall apply to a person to whom section 75(1) applies insofar as such person is acting in the course of the employment which gives rise to the application of that section. (Amended 50 of 1982 s. 5; 60 of 1994 s. 45)

section.name: s73A
section.heading: Indemnity rules

subsection.leadIn: The Council may make rules (in this Ordinance referred to as indemnity rules) concerning indemnity against loss arising from claims in respect of any description of civil liability incurred—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by a solicitor or former solicitor in connection with his practice or with any trust or of which he is or formerly was a trustee;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by an employee of a solicitor or former solicitor in connection with that solicitor’s practice or with any trust of which that solicitor or the employee is or formerly was a trustee.

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of providing such indemnity, indemnity rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may authorize or require the Society, by itself or jointly with the Society of Notaries, to establish and maintain a fund or funds;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may authorize or require the Society, by itself or jointly with the Society of Notaries, to take out and maintain insurance with authorized insurers;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: may require solicitors or any specified class of solicitors to take out and maintain insurance with authorized insurers. (Amended 27 of 1998 s. 5)

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of subsections (1) and (2), indemnity rules—

paragraph.name: a
b
c
d
paragraph.content: may prescribe the conditions which an insurance policy must satisfy for the purposes of subsection (2)(c);

paragraph.name: e
f
paragraph.content: may specify circumstances in which, where a solicitor (not being a solicitor who is exempt from complying with the rules) for whom indemnity is provided has failed to comply with the rules, the Society or insurers may take proceedings against him in respect of sums paid by way of indemnity in connection with a matter in relation to which he has failed to comply;

paragraph.name: fa
paragraph.content: may make provision for the better carrying out of section 7AD; (Added 22 of 2012 s. 8)

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: may specify circumstances in which solicitors are exempt from the rules;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: may empower the Council to take such steps as they consider necessary or expedient to ascertain whether or not the rules are being, or have been, complied with; and (Amended 22 of 2012 s. 8)

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: may contain incidental, procedural or supplementary provisions.

subsection.content: If any solicitor (not being a solicitor who is exempt from complying with indemnity rules) fails to comply with the rules any person may make a complaint in respect of that failure to the Tribunal Convenor of the Solicitors Disciplinary Tribunal Panel. (Amended 60 of 1994 s. 46)

The Society shall have power, without prejudice to any of its other powers, to carry into effect any arrangements which it considers necessary or expedient for the purpose of indemnity under this section.
Every rule made by the Council under this section shall be subject to the prior approval of the Chief Justice.

No rule made under this section shall apply to a person to whom section 75 applies in so far as such person is acting in the course of the employment which gives rise to the application of that section. (Amended 50 of 1982 s. 6)

subsection.def: For the avoidance of doubt, it is declared that in subsection (1)(a) and (b), practice (執業業務), in relation to a solicitor, means acting as a solicitor or the business of acting as a solicitor, whether as a partner, sole practitioner, assistant solicitor or consultant in a Hong Kong firm or as an employee of a non-solicitor employer. (Added 10 of 2005 s. 186)

section.name: s73B
section.heading: Fees for continuing legal education courses
section.content: The Council may by resolution determine the fees that must be paid for continuing legal education courses.

section.name: s73C
section.heading: Council may delegate
section.content: The Council may delegate to any person or to a committee of the Council any of the powers or duties granted or imposed on the Council or the Society under this Ordinance, other than the power to make rules under sections 73 and 73A.

section.name: s73CA
section.heading: Power of Assessment Board to make rules

subsection.leadIn: The Assessment Board may make rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to applications for higher rights of audience made under section 39H, to provide for—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the requirements referred to in section 39I(1)(c), including any requirement regarding possession or acquisition of qualifications, completion of courses or training, or passing of assessments or examinations or exemptions from assessments or examinations, relating to advocacy skills, practice and procedure applicable to courts, ethics or other matters;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the information referred to in section 39J(1)(b);

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the fee referred to in section 39J(1)(c);

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: the alternative requirements referred to in section 39L(1)(a), including any requirement regarding possession or acquisition of advocacy or litigation experience (including experience in relation to tribunal or arbitration proceedings), or judicial or quasi-judicial experience (including experience as a member of any tribunal or as an arbitrator);

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: any enquiries made by the Board with the Council under section 39M(1)(a), including the manner in which the Council is to provide information to the Board as a result of the enquiries;

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: any requirements made by the Board in respect of the applicants under section 39M(1)(b), including the manner in which the applicants are to comply with the requirements and the procedure at any interview conducted as a result of the requirements; and

subparagraph.name: vii
subparagraph.content: any other matters relating to the applications or determination of the applications; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to the Board and its members, to provide for—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the procedure of the Board, including the procedure relating to meetings of the Board, and written resolutions adopted as decisions of the Board without a meeting of the Board;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the disclosure of information by members of the Board having actual or potential interest in matters before the Board, and any related matters, including the imposition, despite section 39G, of restrictions on the participation by the members in the performance of any function of the Board (whether by reference to attendance or voting at meetings or approval of written resolutions or otherwise);

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the appointment of persons to act in the place of the members referred to in subparagraph (ii) (whether as the chairperson or other members of the Board);

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: the appointment of members of the Board as members of committees for the purposes of section 73CB, and the resignation or removal of members of the committees, and the procedure of the committees; and

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: any other matters relating to the Board and its members.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), any rules made under subsection (1)(a)(i) that provide for requirements regarding completion of any courses or training, or passing of any assessments or examinations, may provide for—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the persons or organizations by or on behalf of whom or which the courses or training, or the assessments or examinations, are provided or organized, or the approval of those persons or organizations;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to the courses or training—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the arrangements for the courses or training, including the form, length and content, and the manner of conduct, of the courses or training; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the approval of the courses or training;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: in relation to the assessments or examinations—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the arrangements for the assessments or examinations, including the standards or criteria to be met by individuals in order to pass the assessments or examinations, and any arrangements for appeal or review in respect of matters concerning the assessments or examinations; and

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the qualifications and conditions for appointment of examiners or other persons undertaking assessment of individuals at the assessments or examinations; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other matters relating to the courses or training, or the assessments or examinations.

section.name: s73CB
section.heading: Assessment Board may delegate

subsection.content: The Assessment Board may delegate to any committee of the Board any of its powers or duties in relation to any interview conducted as a result of a requirement made by the Board under section 39M(1)(b).

subsection.leadIn: For the purposes of subsection (1), the Assessment Board may establish a committee of the Board by appointing as members of the committee at least 3 members of the Board, of whom—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: one must be a member of the Board appointed under section 39E(3)(b)(i);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: one must be a member of the Board appointed under section 39E(3)(b)(ii); and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: one must be a member of the Board appointed under section 39E(3)(b)(iii).

subsection.content: Subject to the other provisions of this Ordinance, a committee established under subsection (2) may regulate its own procedure.
Any delegation under subsection (1) may be made generally or in relation to any particular case (whether in relation to any particular interview or interviews or otherwise).

section.name: s73D
section.heading: Power of Council of Society of Notaries to make rules

subsection.leadIn: The Council of the Society of Notaries may make rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: providing for—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the requirements to be complied with by persons applying for appointment as a notary public under section 40A;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the professional practice, conduct and discipline of notaries public and their employees;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the restriction of payment of commission to unqualified persons; and

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: for the purpose of harmonizing the relationship of notaries inter se and, with the prior approval of the Bar Council and the Council of the Law Society, as the case may be, governing the relationship of notaries public and solicitors and barristers respectively;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: regulating the issue to notaries public of practising certificates and the fees payable for, the conditions of issue of, the manner of applying for, the period and form of, the publication of the issue and the suspension of such practising certificates and generally in relation to practising certificates;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: providing for the conduct of any inquiry by a Notaries Public Disciplinary Tribunal;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: respecting the examinations to be passed by persons applying for appointment as notaries public under section 40A and the fees payable to the Council of the Society of Notaries in connection with such examinations;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: enabling the Council of the Society of Notaries to exempt any person from compliance with the provisions of any such rules and to impose and enforce conditions upon which such exemption may be granted in any particular case;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: prescribing any thing which, under this Ordinance, is to be or may be prescribed by the Council of the Society of Notaries.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting the effect of subsection (1)(a)(ii), rules made under that paragraph may provide—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the circumstances in which employees of notaries public shall be liable to be disciplined;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the bringing of disciplinary proceedings against employees of notaries public; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: for the sanctions that may be imposed in respect of breaches of discipline by employees of notaries public,

subsection.continued: and such rules may provide that any provision of Part IV dealing with the discipline of notaries public (including the appointment of members of the Notaries Public Disciplinary Tribunal Panel to constitute a Notaries Public Disciplinary Tribunal to inquire into the conduct of a notary public) shall apply in relation to employees of notaries public.

subsection.content: Every rule made by the Council of the Society of Notaries under this section shall be subject to the prior approval of the Chief Justice.

editorialNote.content: For the saving provision in relation to the amendment made by section 4 of the Legal Practitioners (Amendment) Ordinance 1998 (27 of 1998), please see section 6 of the Ordinance.

section.name: s73E
section.heading: Indemnity rules for notaries public

subsection.leadIn: The Council of the Society of Notaries may make rules concerning indemnity against loss arising from claims in respect of any description of civil liability incurred—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by a notary public or former notary public in connection with his practice; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by an employee or a former employee of a notary public or former notary public in connection with that notary public’s practice.

subsection.leadIn: For the purpose of providing such indemnity, rules made under this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may authorize or require the Society of Notaries, by itself or jointly with the Law Society, to establish and maintain a fund or funds;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may authorize or require the Society of Notaries, by itself or jointly with the Law Society, to take out and maintain insurance with authorized insurers;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: may require notaries public or any specified class of notaries public to take out and maintain insurance with authorized insurers.

subsection.leadIn: Without prejudice to the generality of subsections (1) and (2), rules made under this section—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: may specify the terms and conditions on which indemnity is to be available, and any circumstances in which the right to it is to be excluded or modified;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: may provide for the management, administration and protection of any fund maintained by virtue of subsection (2)(a) and require notaries public or any class of notaries public to make payments to any such fund;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: may require notaries public or any class of notaries public to make payments by way of premium on any insurance policy maintained by the Society of Notaries by virtue of subsection (2)(b);

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: may prescribe the conditions which an insurance policy must satisfy for the purposes of subsection (2)(c);

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: may authorize the Society of Notaries to determine the amount of any payments required by the rules, subject to such limits, or in accordance with such provisions, as may be prescribed by the rules;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: may specify circumstances in which, where a notary public (not being a notary public who is exempt from complying with the rules) for whom indemnity is provided has failed to comply with the rules, the Society of Notaries or insurers may take proceedings against him in respect of sums paid by way of indemnity in connection with a matter in relation to which he has failed to comply;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: may specify circumstances in which notaries public are exempt from the rules made under this section;

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: may empower the Council of the Society of Notaries to take such steps as they consider necessary or expedient to ascertain whether or not the rules are being complied with; and

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: may contain incidental, procedural or supplementary provisions.

subsection.content: The Society of Notaries shall have power, without prejudice to any of its other powers, to carry into effect any arrangements which it considers necessary or expedient for the purpose of indemnity under this section.
Every rule made by the Council of the Society of Notaries under this section shall be subject to the prior approval of the Chief Justice.

editorialNote.content: For the saving provision in relation to the amendment made by section 4 of the Legal Practitioners (Amendment) Ordinance 1998 (27 of 1998), please see section 6 of the Ordinance.

section.name: s73F
section.heading: Council of Society of Notaries may delegate
section.content: The Council of the Society of Notaries may delegate to any person or to a committee of the Council of the Society of Notaries any of the powers or duties granted or imposed on the Society of Notaries or its Council under this Ordinance, other than the power to make rules under sections 73D and 73E.

editorialNote.content: For the saving provision in relation to the amendment made by section 4 of the Legal Practitioners (Amendment) Ordinance 1998 (27 of 1998), please see section 6 of the Ordinance.

section.name: s74
section.heading: Costs Committee

subsection.leadIn: There is hereby established a Costs Committee consisting of the following persons—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a judge of the Court of First Instance appointed by the Chief Justice as Chairman; (Replaced 52 of 1980 s. 2. Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Registrar of the High Court or a senior deputy registrar or deputy registrar of the High Court; (Amended 25 of 1998 s. 2; 10 of 2005 s. 176)

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: for the purposes of the Solicitors (General) Costs Rules (Cap. 159 sub. leg. G), the Director of Lands, or his representative approved by the Chief Justice; (Replaced 8 of 1993 s. 21. Amended L.N. 291 of 1993)

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: the President and one of the Vice-Presidents of the Society and 2 members of the Society nominated by the Society and approved by the Chief Justice; (Amended 70 of 1991 s. 12; 94 of 1997 s. 13)

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: 3 persons appointed by the Chief Executive who, in the opinion of the Chief Executive, can represent the interests of consumers of legal services. (Added 94 of 1997 s. 13. Amended 11 of 1999 s. 3)

subsection.name: 1A
subsection.content: None of the persons appointed under subsection(1)(e) may be a legal practitioner or a public officer. (Added 94 of 1997 s. 13)
The quorum for a meeting of the Costs Committee is the Chairman and 5 members. (Replaced 94 of 1997 s. 13)

subsection.leadIn: The Costs Committee may make rules—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: providing for the remuneration of solicitors in respect of non-contentious business;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prescribing that, as regards the mode of remuneration, it shall be according to the scale of rates or percentage varying or not in different classes of business, or by a gross sum, or by a fixed sum for each document prepared or perused, without regard to length, or in any other mode, or partly in one mode and partly in another;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: regulating the amount of remuneration with reference to all or any of the following, among other, considerations, that is to say—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the position of the party for whom the solicitor is concerned in the business, that is, whether as vendor or purchaser, lessor or lessee, mortgagor or mortgagee, and the like;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: the place where, and the circumstances in which, the business or any part thereof is transacted;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: the amount of the capital money or rent to which the business relates;

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: the skill, labour and responsibility involved therein on the part of the solicitor;

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: the number and importance of the documents prepared or perused, without regard to length;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: authorizing and regulating the taking by a solicitor from his client of security for payment or otherwise, which may become due to him under any such rule; and

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: authorizing and regulating the allowance of interest on costs and expenses.

subsection.content: Every rule made under this section shall be subject to the prior approval of the Chief Justice.

So long as any rules made under this section are in operation, taxation of bills of costs of solicitors in respect of non-contentious business shall, subject to the provisions of section 5, be regulated by such rules.

section.name: s74A
section.heading: Standing Committee on Legal Education and Training

subsection.content: There is established by this section a Standing Committee on Legal Education and Training.

subsection.leadIn: The functions of the committee are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: to keep under review, evaluate and assess—

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: the system and provision of legal education and training in Hong Kong;

subparagraph.name: ii

paragraph.name: b
c
paragraph.content: to make recommendations on matters referred to in paragraphs (a) and (b); and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: to collect and disseminate information concerning the system of legal education and training in Hong Kong.

subsection.leadIn: The committee shall consist of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: 17 members appointed by the Chief Executive of whom— (Amended 10 of 2005 s. 184)

subparagraph.name: i
subparagraph.content: 2 shall be persons nominated by the Chief Justice;

subparagraph.name: ii
subparagraph.content: 1 shall be a person nominated by the Secretary for Justice;

subparagraph.name: iii
subparagraph.content: 1 shall be a person nominated by the Secretary for Education; (Amended L.N. 130 of 2007)

subparagraph.name: iv
subparagraph.content: 2 shall be persons nominated by the Society;

subparagraph.name: v
subparagraph.content: 2 shall be persons nominated by the Hong Kong Bar Association;

subparagraph.name: vi
subparagraph.content: 2 shall be persons nominated by the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Hong Kong;

subparagraph.name: vii
subparagraph.content: 2 shall be persons nominated by the President of the City University of Hong Kong;

subparagraph.name: viia
subparagraph.content: 2 shall be persons nominated by the Vice-Chancellor of The Chinese University of Hong Kong; (Added 10 of 2005 s. 184)

subparagraph.name: viii
subparagraph.content: 2 shall be members of the public; and

subparagraph.name: ix
subparagraph.content: 1 shall be a person nominated by the Federation for Self-financing Tertiary Education, a non-profit-making educational organization, from among its members which provide continuing legal education courses in Hong Kong; and (Amended 18 of 2014 s. 159)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a chairman appointed by the Chief Executive after consultation with the persons and organizations making nominations pursuant to paragraph (a)(i) to (viia) and (ix). (Amended 10 of 2005 s. 184)

subsection.content: A member of the committee who is unable to attend a meeting of the committee, except for a member appointed pursuant to subsection (3)(a)(viii), may, subject to the consent of the chairman, send a substitute to attend the meeting in his place and the substitute shall be deemed to be a member of the committee for the purpose of that meeting.
A member of the committee including the chairman shall hold office for a term not exceeding 2 years.
A member of the committee including the chairman may at any time resign from the committee by giving notice in writing of his resignation to the Chief Executive.
The Secretary for Justice may publish notice of the appointment or termination of membership of a member (including the chairman) appointed pursuant to this section in the Gazette.
The committee shall report annually to the Chief Executive and its annual report shall be tabled in the Legislative Council.
The committee may determine its own procedure.

section.name: s74C
section.heading: Students already enrolled in legal studies in the United Kingdom
section.leadIn: Notwithstanding the repeal and replacement of section 27 by section 7 of the Legal Practitioners (Amendment) Ordinance 2000 (42 of 2000) (the amending Ordinance), where a person, on the day the amending Ordinance is published in the Gazette, is enrolled or registered in, or has been offered a place—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: in a course of studies in the United Kingdom that, on completion, will qualify him for a vocational course leading to admission as a barrister in the United Kingdom;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: in the Bar Vocational Course in the United Kingdom; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: in an external course of studies in Hong Kong offered by an institution in the United Kingdom that, on completion, will qualify him for a vocational course leading to admission as a barrister in the United Kingdom,

section.continued: the person may, instead of complying with the requirements established under section 27 for admission as a barrister, elect to be admitted under section 27 as that section existed before its repeal by the amending Ordinance, provided he—

paragraph.name: i
paragraph.content: has been called to the Bar in England or Northern Ireland or admitted as an advocate in Scotland;

paragraph.name: ii
paragraph.content: qualifies for admission under the other criteria established under the repealed section 27(1)(b), (c) and (e) and (1A); and

paragraph.name: iii
paragraph.content: applies for admission not later than 31 December 2004.

section.name: s74D
section.heading: Lawyers employed in Department of Justice

subsection.content: Notwithstanding the repeal of section 27A by section 8 of the Legal Practitioners (Amendment) Ordinance 2000 (42 of 2000) (the amending Ordinance), where a person, on or before the date appointed by the Secretary for Justice by notice in the Gazette for the coming into operation of section 8(2) of the amending Ordinance, meets the requirements in section 27A(1)(a) to (d), as that section existed before its repeal, the Court may at any time admit such person as a barrister of the High Court of Hong Kong in accordance with the said section 27A(1).
The Court shall not admit as a barrister, under subsection (1), more than 4 persons in any period of 12 months.
For the avoidance of doubt, section 27A(1)(e) and (3) does not apply to admission as a barrister under this section.

section.name: s75
section.heading: Saving

subsection.leadIn: Nothing in this Ordinance shall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prejudice or affect any rights or privileges of any legal officer within the meaning of section 2 of the Legal Officers Ordinance (Cap. 87), any person holding an appointment under section 3(1) of the Legal Aid Ordinance (Cap. 91) or any person deemed to be a legal officer for the purpose of the Legal Officers Ordinance (Cap. 87) by virtue of section 3(3) of the Director of Intellectual Property (Establishment) Ordinance (Cap. 412) or section 75(3) of the Bankruptcy Ordinance (Cap. 6) or require any such person or any clerk, trainee solicitor or officer appointed to act for him to be admitted in any case where it would not have been necessary for him to be admitted if this Ordinance had not been enacted; or (Amended 1 of 1981 s. 6; 50 of 1982 s. 7; 35 of 1990 s. 13; 70 of 1991 s. 13; 39 of 1992 s. 12; 8 of 1993 s. 22; 11 of 1999 s. 3)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: affect any enactment empowering any person, whether or not a solicitor or a barrister, to conduct, convene or otherwise act in relation to any legal proceedings. (Amended 60 of 1994 s. 47)

subsection.content: The Court of First Instance, on the application of the Council, may order that no payment shall be made without the leave of the court by any person (whether or not named in the order) of any money held by him (in whatever manner and whether it was received before or after the making of the order) on behalf of the solicitor or his firm or the foreign lawyer or his firm.

No order under this section shall take effect in relation to any person to whom it applies unless the Council has served a copy of the order on him (whether or not he is named in it) and, in the case of a bank or other financial institution, has indicated at which of its branches the Council believes that the money to which the order relates is held.

A person shall not be treated as having disobeyed an order under this section by making a payment of money if he satisfies the Court that he exercised due diligence to ascertain whether it was money to which the order related but nevertheless failed to ascertain that the order related to it.
This section does not apply where the powers conferred by this Schedule are exercisable by virtue of section 26C of this Ordinance.

Without prejudice to section 1 if the Council passes a resolution to the effect that any sums of money to which this section applies, and the right to recover or receive them, shall vest in the Council, all such sums shall vest accordingly (whether they were received by the person holding them before or after the Council’s resolution) and shall be held by the Council on trust to exercise in relation to them the powers conferred by this Schedule and subject thereto upon trust for the persons beneficially entitled to them.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the powers conferred by this section are exercisable by virtue of section 26A of this Ordinance, to all sums of money held by or on behalf of the solicitor or his firm or the foreign lawyer or his firm in connection with his practice or with any trust of which he is or formerly was a trustee;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where they are exercisable by virtue of section 26B of this Ordinance, to all sums of money in any client account; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: where they are exercisable by virtue of section 26C of this Ordinance, to all sums of money held by or on behalf of the solicitor or his firm or the foreign lawyer or his firm in connection with the trust or other matter to which the complaint relates.

subsection.content: Except where section 4 applies, the Council shall serve on the solicitor or his firm or the foreign lawyer or his firm and on any other person having possession of sums of money to which this section applies a certified copy of the Council’s resolution and a notice prohibiting the payment out of any such sums of money.

Within 8 days of the service of a notice under subsection (3), the person on whom it was served, on giving not less than 48 hours’ notice in writing to the Council and (if the notice under subsection (3) gives the name of the solicitor instructed by the Council) to that solicitor, may apply to the Court of First Instance for an order directing the Council to withdraw the notice.
If the Court makes such an order, it shall have power also to make such other order with respect to the matter as it may think fit.

subsection.leadIn: If any person on whom a notice has been served under subsection (3) pays out sums of money at a time when such payment is prohibited by the notice—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: he shall be guilty of an offence and liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 5; and(Amended E.R. 2 of 2019)

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the Court of First Instance may, on the application of the Council, order that person to comply with the requirements of the notice within such time as may be specified in the order.

section.name: s3
section.content: Without prejudice to sections 1 and 2, if the Court of First Instance is satisfied, on an application by the Council, that there is reason to suspect that any person holds money on behalf of the solicitor or his firm or the foreign lawyer or his firm, the Court may require that person to give the Council information as to any such money and the accounts in which it is held.

section.name: s4
section.content: On the death of a solicitor or foreign lawyer who immediately before his death was practising as a solicitor in his own name or as a sole solicitor or foreign lawyer under a firm name, the right to operate on or otherwise deal with any banking account in the name of the solicitor or his firm or the foreign lawyer or his firm, being an account in the title of which the word “client” appears, shall, notwithstanding anything in this Ordinance or otherwise to the contrary, vest in the Council to the exclusion of any personal representatives of such solicitor or foreign lawyer and shall be exercisable as from the death of the solicitor or foreign lawyer.

content.leadIn: Subject to the service of any notice under section 2(3), and to any application that may be made under section 2(4), the Council or any person in that behalf appointed by the Council may withdraw the moneys, or from time to time any part of the moneys, in any banking account in the name of the solicitor or his firm or the foreign lawyer or his firm, and any moneys in the office of the solicitor or his firm or the foreign lawyer or his firm due to or held on behalf of his clients, and pay them into a special account or special accounts in the name of the Council or such person appointed as aforesaid and may operate on, and otherwise deal with, such special account or accounts as the solicitor or his firm or the foreign lawyer or his firm might have operated on, or otherwise dealt with, that banking account:
content.proviso: Provided that a banker with whom such special account or accounts is or are kept shall be under no obligation to ascertain whether that account or those accounts is or are being so operated on or otherwise dealt with.

section.name: s6
section.content: In any case where the Council is unable to ascertain the person to whom any moneys referred to in a notice served under section 2(3) belong or where the Council otherwise thinks it expedient so to do, the Council may apply to the Court of First Instance for directions as to the transfer of such moneys.

subsection.leadIn: The Council may give notice to the solicitor or his firm or the foreign lawyer or his firm requiring the production or delivery to any person appointed by the Council at a time and place to be fixed by the Council—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: where the powers conferred by this Schedule are exercisable by virtue of section 26A of this Ordinance, of all documents in the possession of the solicitor or his firm or the foreign lawyer or his firm in connection with his practice or with any controlled trust; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: where they are exercisable by virtue of section 26C of this Ordinance, of all documents in the possession of the solicitor or his firm or the foreign lawyer or his firm in connection with the trust or other matters to which the complaint relates (whether or not they relate also to other matters).

subsection.content: The person appointed by the Council may take possession of any such documents on behalf of the Council.

Except in a case where an application has been made to the Court of First Instance under subsection (4), if any person having possession of any such documents refuses, neglects or otherwise fails to comply with a requirement under subsection (1), he shall be guilty of an offence and liable on summary conviction to a fine at level 5.(Amended E.R. 2 of 2019)

The Court of First Instance, on the application of the Council, may order a person required to produce or deliver documents under subsection (1) to produce or deliver them to any person appointed by the Council at such time and place as may be specified in the order, and authorize him to take possession of them on behalf of the Council.

If on an application by the Council the Court of First Instance is satisfied that there is reason to suspect that documents in relation to which the powers conferred by subsection (1) are exercisable have come into the possession of some person other than the solicitor or his firm or the foreign lawyer or his firm, the Court may order that person to produce or deliver the documents to any person appointed by the Council at such time and place as may be specified in the order and authorize him to take possession of them on behalf of the Council.

On making an order under this section, or at any later time, the Court, on the application of the Council, may authorize a person appointed by the Council to enter any premises (using such force as is reasonably necessary) to search for and take possession of any documents to which the order relates.

Upon taking possession of any such documents, the Council shall serve upon the solicitor or foreign lawyer and every person from whom those documents were received, or from whose premises they were taken by virtue of an order made under this section, a notice giving particulars and the date of taking possession thereof.

Subject to subsection (9) a person upon whom a notice under subsection (7) is served, on giving not less than 48 hours’ notice to the Council and (if the notice under subsection (7) gives the name of the solicitor instructed by the Council) to that solicitor, may apply to the Court of First Instance for an order directing the Council to deliver the documents to such person as the applicant may require.
A notice under subsection (8) shall be given within 8 days of the service of the Council’s notice under subsection (7).

content.leadIn: If no application is made under subsection (8), or if the judge to whom any such application is made directs that the documents shall remain in the custody or control of the Council, the Council may make inquiries to ascertain the person to whom those documents belong and may deal with those documents in accordance with the directions of that person:
content.proviso: Provided that, before dealing with such documents, the Council may take copies of, or extracts from, any such documents.

subsection.content: Without prejudice to the provisions of Part IIA of this Ordinance and this Schedule, the Council may apply to the Court of First Instance for an order as to the disposal or destruction of any documents in its possession by virtue of this section or section 8.
On an application under subsection (8) or (11), the Court may make such order as it thinks fit.

Except so far as its right to do so may be restricted by an order on an application under subsection (8) or (11), the Council may take copies of or extracts from any documents in its possession by virtue of this section or section 8 and require any person to whom it is proposed that such documents shall be delivered, as a condition precedent to delivery, to give a reasonable undertaking to supply copies or extracts to the Council.

The Court of First Instance, on the application of the Council, may from time to time order that for such time not exceeding 18 months as the Court thinks fit postal packets (as defined in section 2 of the Post Office Ordinance (Cap. 98)) addressed to the solicitor or his firm or the foreign lawyer or his firm at any place or places mentioned in the order shall be directed to the Council or any person appointed by the Council at any other address therein mentioned; and the Council, or that person on its behalf, may take possession of any such packets received at that address.

Where such an order is made the Council shall pay to the Postmaster General the like charges (if any), as would have been payable for the redirection of the packets by virtue of any scheme made under regulation 32 of the Post Office Regulations (Cap. 98 sub. leg. A), if the addressee had permanently ceased to occupy the premises to which they were addressed and had applied to the Postmaster General to redirect them to him at the address mentioned in the order.
This section does not apply where the powers conferred by this Schedule are exercisable by virtue of section 26C of this Ordinance.

section.name: s9
section.content: The powers in relation to sums of money and documents conferred by this Schedule shall be exercisable notwithstanding any lien on them or right to their possession.

section.name: s10
section.content: Subject to any order for the payment of costs that may be made on an application to the Court under this Schedule, any costs incurred by the Council for the purposes of this Schedule, including, without prejudice to the generality of this section, the costs of any person exercising powers under this Schedule on behalf of the Council, shall be paid by the solicitor or foreign lawyer or his personal representatives and shall be recoverable from him or them as a debt owing to the Council.

section.name: s11
section.content: Where an offence under this Schedule committed by a body corporate is proved to have been committed with the consent or connivance of, or to be attributable to any neglect on the part of, any director, manager, secretary or other similar officer of the body corporate or any person who was purporting to act in any such capacity, he, as well as the body corporate, shall be guilty of that offence and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.

section.name: s12
section.content: Any application to the Court of First Instance under this Schedule may be disposed of in chambers.

section.name: s13
section.content: The Council may do all things which are reasonably necessary for the purpose of facilitating the exercise of its powers under this Schedule.

section.name: s14
section.content: Any requirement of notice under this Schedule shall be made in writing under the hand of such person as may be appointed by the Council for the purpose and may be served on any person either by personal service or by being sent by registered post addressed to his last known place of business or residence.
